"There must be a vaccine to protect us from whatever it is that Texas is suffering from!"

There is. It's called secession.
Mutts and mongrels do not equate. One is endearing, the other offensive.
Remember Romney's "dog food?"

@Mark in Chicago

From the Merriam-Webster dictionary:

Mutt (n): a DOG with parents of different breeds.
1. a stupid or insignificant person : fool.
2. a mongrel dog: cur

Synonyms:

airhead, birdbrain, blockhead, bonehead, bubblehead, chowderhead, chucklehead, clodpoll (or clodpole), clot [British], cluck, clunk, cretin, cuddy (or cuddie) [British dialect], deadhead, dim bulb [slang], dimwit, dip, dodo, dolt, donkey, doofus [slang], dope, dork [slang], dullard, dumbbell, dumbhead, dum-dum, dummkopf, dummy, dunce, dunderhead, fathead, gander, golem, goof, goon, half-wit, hammerhead, hardhead, ignoramus, imbecile, jackass, know-nothing, knucklehead, lamebrain, loggerhead [chiefly dialect], loon, lump, lunkhead, meathead, mome [archaic], moron, mug [chiefly British], idiot, natural, nimrod [slang], nincompoop, ninny, ninnyhammer, nit [chiefly British], nitwit, noddy, noodle, numskull (or numbskull), oaf, pinhead, prat [British], ratbag [chiefly Australian], saphead, schlub (also shlub) [slang], schnook [slang], simpleton, stock, stupe, stupid, thickhead, turkey, woodenhead, yahoo, yo-yo.

Ted Nugent broke the cardinal rule of 21st century racist politics. He either never learned the fine art of the GOP dog whistle, or in his self-pleasuring frenzy, he grabbed his bullhorn by mistake.

Nugent is only the latest actor to play the role of GOP useful idiot. (see Beck, Glen). He spews the sewage so the actual candidates and overpaid pundits don't have to. He'll come out with a doozy, hog the airwaves for 24 or 48 hours, induce apoplexy in Wolf Blitzer, and finally Rick Perry or some other smirking hypocrite pretends to disown him. Until next time. Until the next corporate-sponsored cable appearance.

Animal metaphors are always fraught. Other faves applied to minorities throughout history are been cockroaches, rats and other vermin.

To really do dog-whistling right, though, look no further than David Brooks's column predicting that America will soon be "A Nation of Mutts." (synonymous with mongrels, but tamer-sounding.) In his usual fashion, Brooks demeaned biracial, minority and ethnically diverse people by offering up phony praise to diversity. The subtext, of course, is that America will no longer be a nation of purebreds. Eeeeek!

Brooks didn't have to apologize to those who had the unmitigated gall to be offended, because if they were offended, they'd simply misread his column. It's the fine art of the dog-whistle. Cringe-worthy but not puke-worthy.

Meanwhile, for unsophisticated bigotry, there's always Ted Nugent and his bullhorn of plenty.
That concert was 35 years ago.  My, how time flies!

D-Ferg:

You are right that the analysis of 52 cards can be carried out with a 4 or 5 dimensional state Markov chain, which Henk alluded to previously. Earlier I was deterred by the mistaken first impression that the complexity would be close to evaluating all ${52\choose 26}$ paths and scanning for each pair of strategies, and forgot this is a Markov chain. Clear headed good work!
I do get a kick out of you, John.  Sorry for the premature preveal, but I won't be checking back tonight.

BARTOK for DVORAK, argh!  Some orchestral music in the northeast, but a missed opportunity for some pop music clues along the equator:  "Santana's woman?" for 33A (not performed at Woodstock); "Hit from Duran Duran's second self-titled album" for 42A.

Some people are wondering what the counterargument to Say's Law is. Here's the answer:

Demand is fundamentally a *rate*.

You would never say, "At current prices, the economy demands a billion dollars of goods and services." Instead you would say, "At current prices, the economy demands a billion dollars of goods and services *per day*."

Say's Law makes no sense when you think of demand at a rate. Suppose the government taxes a dollar from you to spend on highways. When that tax is levied, it does indeed remove a dollar from your bank's reserves. But who cares? You can't figure out the rate of demand by looking at where dollars *are*. You have to figure out how often they're spent.

There are many reasons to believe that, when the government taxes and spends its citizens' money, it increases the rate at which dollars are spent. And under normal circumstances that increases demand.

Louis Derry, Feb 20th post

Dear Mr. Derry,

Go back, if you will, please, to Ries et al, op. cit., Geology, Dec 2009, p 1131-1134.

See Figure 1 for the calcification rates at an aragonite saturation state of 2.0. This corresponds to 600 ppm CO2 in the atmosphere. We can expect that CO2 content in ca. 2130 a.d.

Recall that Harrison's original post concerned the next 100 years. I agree that that is a reasonable policy-relevant horizon.

So Ries's data show that, in the next 100 years, the following sea creatures will INCREASE their calcification rates:

Blue crabs, shrimp, lobster, limpets, purple urchins, coralline red algae, and halimeda.

No change is expected for blue mussels, temperate coral, pencil urchins, hard clams, conch, and serpulid worms.

In the next 100 years, the calcification rates of periwinkles, bay scallops, oysters, whelks and soft clams may decline but still within the error bands of the present (400 ppm CO2) environment.

How, I ask you, can any responsible scientist maintain that this is a catastrophe any time in the next 100 years?

Re coccoliths, see Halloran, P.R., et al, Biogeosciences 5:1651-1655, 2008. I quote "in the real ocean the larger coccolithophore species increase their calcification in response to anthropogenic CO2 release"

Re coral reefs, see Takahasi, A, Coral Reefs 32: 305-314 2013 "no evidence of CO2 impact on bleaching"

Is this a catastrophe? I think not.

Stop the hyperbole, sir, I urge you. It does you no credit.
Yeah, but is Oklahoma really much better?
I grew up in Texas. I got out in the nick of time.

My favourite man in the field is Leo Szilard. Despite what-all he set in motion, he seems to have been about as far from being a mad scientist as possible. OT by virtue of CYCLOTRONS.

First met him by reading Voice of the Dolphins.
Forgive me for thinking already that there is something wrong with Texas, inasmuch as its inhabitants appear to be happy with the U.S. Senate's resident obstruction, Ted Cruz.

Linda, are you saying that George W. Bush, Rick Perry, Tom DeLay, Phil Graham, Louie Gohmert, Blake Farenthold, Steve Stockman, Ted Cruz et.al. weren't already evidence enough?  I thought it had been pretty apparent that there was something "wrong" at least since Ann Richards was Governor.  But let's not forget that there is a sizable -- if minority -- contingent of moderate and progressive Texans who deserve our respect and support.

If Texans elect Greg Abbott for governor after he hung around with Ted Nugent, then there really is something wrong with that state. I say this as someone who lived in Texas until I was nineteen years old.
But ... the United States has done nothing in Syria, Ukraine, or Venezuela.

The EU will impose its austerity on Ukraine.

Russia would have provided Ukraine billions of dollars in subsidies and cut the price Ukraine pays for Russian gas.

Another geopolitical football.

Provide the USA political unrest and they will use it as a pretext for arming homicidal thugs, destabilizing the economy, and regime change.

Syria, Ukraine, Venezuela.

Pushing the EU and ultimately NATO onto Russia's doorstep is another step down the road to war.

"WHY ISN'T RUSSIA, ALONG WITH UKRAINE, PURSUING CLOSER TIES WITH THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY."

You should ask that the EU. Russia wants a deal that includes both Ukraine and them. The EU refuses. It looks like some Cold War leftovers have too much power inside the EU.

Russia feels threatened by the West and rightly so. NATO is Russia's antagonist, Kosovo bombing in the late 90s, toppling all governments aligned with Russia, Libya, Syria, and American NGOs are pouring money into ukraine to undermine Russia. Oh and missile defense.

Your idealism is refreshing. Although logical EU has flaws, as Corp-Banksters still run national governments and egotistic EU parliament.

Nordic countries were good before EU, now and would be good alone. Some newly joined countries have rotten and corrupted systems comparable with the worst African.

On top of all these, dubious EU benevolence to Black African and Islamic immigration might incinerate new, already simmering, but unnecessary animosities and frictions in future.

Russia with its huge energetic and human potentials doesn't need Global Bankster's sociopathy, they have their own. Under "Czar" Putin, Russian economy is growing, Military is getting back to its Soviet era power and domestic oligarchs rule the country, instead of those Global "cousins". If US/EU-Russian relations could remain in some sort of "partnership", tepid tolerance or whatever, world will remain "cool".

On top of all these, Russian nation on long run might remain "miraculously" healthier, without dubious EU immigrational "enrichment", not to mention LGBT rampancy. At least on those issues it might become a raw model to EU somewhere in the future.

As of Ukraine, it is obviously divided country and it should separate peacefully in two independent states, similarly as Czech-Slovaks or quite likely risk a bloody civil war as Yugoslavia had.

I don't understand why Russia, under Putin, is committed to creating a "Eurasian Union" as a counterpart to the European Union.

This is nonsense and madness on the order of Uncle Adolph.

Adolph wanted a unitary Germany not integrated with Europe, but with a large Eurasian hinterland. That was an absurd dream that could never come even with the infliction of deaths.

After losing WWII, the idea of international communitarian organization in Europe gained credibility. The European Community has largely settled the issue of Europe's political and ethno/cultural fragmentation. Its a fairly sophisticated solution, and not without its problems, but by and large, it works. Members of the European Community enjoy some of the highest living standards in the world, including peace, prosperity, strong institutions for health and education, civil freedome and civil rights. The happiest people in the world, the Danes, live inside that union. What's not to like?

So the question shouldn't be whether Ukraine should align with Europe or Russia, the question should be, WHY ISN'T RUSSIA, ALONG WITH UKRAINE, PURSUING CLOSER TIES WITH THE EUROPEAN COMMUNITY.

There is no purpose to Putin's Eurasian Union other than to conform to his ego, and his anachronistic idea of a nation state.

Europe has found a way for Nations to live together in peace, prosperity, fairness and freedom. That should be Ukraine's and Russia's future. Indeed, it should be all of ours.

Reply to robertgeary9, portland, or

San Antonio is an entity unto itself -- not really akin to other Texas cities. The regional differences in Texas are striking; Houston has become more ethnically diverse, with a large population of foreign-born professionals. Dallas has the reputation of being a wealthy, status-obsessed city, but is also undergoing rapid demographic changes. Austin is on the cutting-edge of technology and a bastion of liberalism. Texas cities could be regarded as city-states with strong individual personalities.

San Antonio, once known as 'Taco Town' by Texans who did not always appreciate its milieu, has its own cultural flavor and identity. The large Mexican-American population always has and always will influence the friendly, warm ambiente here.

Politics tend to be local in San Antonio, but we are proud to have Julian Castro as our Mayor and Joaquin Castro in Congress. We hope to see them rise on the national political scene. The country needs level-headed, intelligent leaders who stand up for the ideals of democracy and Democratic agendas.

San Antonio is a get-along city that works. We embrace multi-culturalism; living proof that diversity is possible and not a threat.

It doesn't feel terribly conservative here. Despite differences we thrive. We are hopefully a good example for the rest of Texas and the country.

Viva San Antonio !
Ted Nugent's remarks on President Obama are despicable, and candidates who embrace him are tainted by Nugent's racism.  Ugh.

Otherwise it seems like a mismatch, and this is why supply-siders and demand-siders talk past each other. Demand-siders expect the supply-siders to care about employment in one nation returning to full employment levels, when supply-siders expect (cheaper wages aside) workers to reposition themselves, in other words emigrate to find work for their individual skill or talent. This would explain to some degree why supply-siders and Austerians, as we have seen here, do not care about creating jobs here but they see value in celebrating nations that have austerity policies in place and have citizens willing, or becoming desperate enough, to emigrate for work. A reallocation of resources.

So this brings up all kinds of issues if this is indeed how Republicans, supply-siders, Austerians, all view supply and demand with regard to employment. And I am not saying I agree with this outlook but it would shed light on why Republicans feel the Fed’s full employment mandate, fiscal stimulus, and monetary stimulus is unnecessary. For American workers they are very necessary economic tools but for global workers it depends.

If we only cared about employment as a global issue then what does that mean to the unemployed in one nation? It looks like Say’s Law holds as global supply and global demand, and it’s as if we are being expected to see ourselves as global citizens and more or less on our own to compete. Capitalism for the masses indeed.
well yeah, but this looks like a great way to send your college kid a little cash once in a while. I'm surprised they haven't introduced me to the service!

Honestly, it's more fun to exchange money with people face to face. And going to the bank to get cash is good exercise (unless you only use drive-up ATMs)!

Maybe someday we won't have to go anywhere or see anyone...

Good night, Martin. Until we meet again....

Structural reform is usually used in conjunction with discussions of unemployment and how that impedes economic recovery.  If there are too many workers in one part of the country and all the jobs are in another-- structural reforms are needed to get the workers to where the jobs are.  Or, if all of the unemployed workers lack the skills to do the jobs that are available-- structural reforms are needed to retrain workers for the change in the job market.  Since there is little to no evidence that all workers need to do is relocate or retrain, there is little support for the need for structural reform.  It is appealing to pols and lazy people (as well as evil people who know they know better) because it requires no modification of behavior or redistribution of resources since it will self correct.  Dr. K champions a demand deficiency explanation.  bc

Wind Surfer, that is the best critique of the government's handling of the crisis that I have read. One paragraph by a non-journalist in Florida summed up the whole mess.

Alas, top management was allowed to stay in the name of liquidity and continuity of management. It appears as if that worked to some extent. But it will not when the next, larger crisis hits.
A lot of US outdoorsmanship with guns is about unabashed environmental destruction. Nugent is a role model for those people.

This Republican condemns Ted Nugent's over-the-top depiction of President Obama. While I have issues with the President as do many Americans, I respect the office and wish him well. He is OUR President, the toughest job in the world.

I, too, thought of the Nazi technique, which takes Nugent’s rant to the level of justifying violence for his listeners.

As your first link points out, in 2012 Nugent said he’d be “dead or in jail by this time next year” if Obama was re-elected.

A gun advocate generating a continuous drumbeat of hate speech increases the risk of a mentally unbalanced listener feeling justified to gun down a politician, as happened with Gabby Giffords, or justified in gunning down African-Americans as happened with Zimmerman and Dunns.

Your first link also states Ted Nugent is a National Rifle Association director. That clarifies why Republicans refuse to condemn Nugent!

And it’s obvious why the NRA opposes mental stability qualifications when one of their directors is making statements we’d expect from someone mentally deranged.

Then at the bottom of the linked piece, it turns out Nugent just signed an endorsement deal with the Outdoor Channel.

“Under this agreement, we will join forces with Ted to become advocates for all enthusiasts who love and live in the outdoors,” said the CEO of the Outdoor Channel.

What a disgusting insult to those of us who stay attached to the outdoor environment and take pride in our outdoor skills! Might want to tell Nugent and Phil Robertson the outdoors is a place, not an excuse.

If I'm Tymokshenko, I'd make my campaign platform:

"Let both Russia and Ukraine pursue closer intergration with the European Community - both have a strong and long lasting legacy in Europe...

Putin's Eurasian Union is an anachronistic absurdity left over from the Cold War. The future of peace and prosperity for the world begins with greater integration and sound, uncorrupt institutions: Europe is the guiding light. Let Ukraine and Russia show the world how to walk out of the darkness of old attitudes into the light of a new future, one with peace, prosperity, civil rights, sound institutions without corruption and sensible integration....

Russia, join us as we seek closer integration with Europe. There is no need for a second 'Eurasian Union' when a valid, sophisticate working one already exist."

This is a stragety of transcendence - rising above the west or east choice. What I think Clinton called constragulation.

It would box Putin in and put him on the defensive. Instead of arguing why Ukraine shouldn't be part of Europe, he has to explain to Russians why they shouldn't be pursuing closer ties to the European Community, why they shouldn't be enjoying a less corrupt government, first class health and education institutions, functioning democracy, higher standard of living, greater prosperty and civil rights.

How many Russians, to say nothing of Ukrainians, wouldn't want the standard of living enjoyed in Prague? Its there's within a generation if they want it.
